abstract: We show the strong-convexity assumption of regularization-based methods for solving bilinear saddle point problems may be relaxed to a weaker notion of  area-convexity  with respect to an alternating bilinear form. This allows bypassing the infamous â   â    barrier for strongly convex regularizers that has stalled progress on a number of algorithmic problems.   Applying area-convex regularization, we present a nearly-linear time approximation algorithm for solving matrix inequality systems  A   X  â �  B  over right-stochastic matrices  X . By combining that algorithm with existing work on preconditioning maximum-flow, we obtain a nearly-linear time approximation algorithm for maximum concurrent flow in undirected graphs: given an undirected, capacitated graph with  m  edges and  k  demand vectors, the algorithm takes � ( mk N  â  1 ) time and outputs  k  flows routing the specified demands with total congestion at most (1+N ) times optimal.
